Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An Investigation of Change and Continuity in Household Consumption in the Hinterlands of Early Nineteenth-Century Hawaii

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Summer Moore will investigate the effects of colonial expansion and, in particular, the market economy on Hawaiian households in the daily lives of indigenous families living in remote regions. Researchers have long studied the processes by which culture contact in colonial settings drives social and cultural shifts at the micro-scale, or household, level. It has often been assumed that social change stemming from colonial interaction, such as adopting new forms of household economic organization, spreads uniformly through indigenous societies. In recent years, scholars have placed increasing emphasis on understanding how individuals and social groups shaped their participation in large-scale social and economic trends initiated by high-status elites in unique and independent ways. This research focuses specifically on colonial-era Hawai'i, examining how groups in isolated areas of the island chain chose to accept, reject, or modify newly introduced household practices based on local needs and concerns. Investigating small-scale, local responses to "top-down" social forces will provide a better understanding of processes of social change in both ancient societies and in the present. Hawaiian and Hawai'i-based students will take part in all phases of work, offering crucial training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate archaeology students in both excavation and laboratory techniques. Such instruction will help increase the representation of Hawaiian archaeologists working in Hawai'i, an under-represented minority group in the field. William & Mary students will assist with the laboratory analysis phase, which will also provide an important opportunity for applied training in archaeological research techniques.

This research will explore how inhabitants of remote, outlying regions under nominal colonial control responded to large-scale social transformations, as well as how these responses may have shifted through time. Using a theoretical framework highlighting the self-determination of local communities, this research focuses on three communities on the N창 Pali Coast of Kaua'i Island, Hawai'i, a remote region located far from Hawai'i's political centers. The N창 Pali Coast is separated from the rest of the island by high cliffs that restrict overland access to the region. Lying in an isolated region at the margins of the newly emerging Hawaiian Kingdom, these sites provide a unique case study to explore responses to nineteenth-century colonialism. This project uses multiple lines of evidence, including household archaeology and information from historical documents, to compare consumption practices on Kaua'i Island's remote N창 Pali Coast to patterns seen in more central parts of the archipelago. If early nineteenth-century N창 Pali Coast households did pursue distinctive economic strategies, it will be compelling evidence that nineteenth-century social and cultural transformations were not progressive and inevitable, as now understood, but instead subject to local negotiation and contestation. This research has implications for understanding local responses not only to European colonialism in the modern era but also to large-scale patterns of social change in historical contexts world-wide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The period after the arrival of Capt. James Cook in Hawai‘i in 1778 was a time of widespread sociopolitical and cultural transformation. One of the most prominent changes was the reorganization of Hawaiian household economies, as households began to connect with Hawai‘i’s emerging market economy and incorporate consumer products into familiar domestic routines. While foreign goods were initially available only to a select few Hawaiians in port towns, such items became increasingly accessible as a consumer economy spread across the archipelago. The prevailing understanding has been that, by the early nineteenth century, Hawaiians in all parts of the archipelago had abandoned traditional domestic practices as foreign goods became increasingly available. In other words, households moved from provisioning themselves through subsistence-level farming and fishing, local craft production, and reciprocal exchange to total participation in the consumer economy. Drawing on recent research that emphasizes the agency of local communities, especially indigenous communities in colonial settings, this project examines nineteenth-century households in one of Hawai‘i’s most remote areas. Specifically, it questions whether residents of these households participated fully in Hawai‘i’s consumer economy or whether they followed alternative trajectories of change, either by preserving traditional practices or forging new ones that would allow them to operate independently of Hawai‘i’s mainstream market economy. This NSF doctoral dissertation improvement grant supported the final phases of Summer Moore’s fieldwork and archival research. The dissertation project integrates multiple methods, including excavation and legacy collections research to investigate the primary research question.

The N? Pali Coast, a remote coastline on the northwestern perimeter of Kaua‘i Island, is one of the most isolated areas of Hawai‘i. This project investigates two communities located in separate valleys along the coast, the communities of Miloli‘i and Nu‘alolo Kai. Using the household as an archaeological unit of analysis, this research examines the organization of domestic economies during the early colonial period. Using evidence such as household artifacts and food remains, it examines whether households in these communities mirrored patterns seen elsewhere in the archipelago or, instead, continued to rely on familiar Hawaiian domestic practices.

The Miloli‘i investigations included test excavations at five possible nineteenth-century house locations, of which four were determined to represent the remains of houses. At one house where the main platform had previously been excavated, additional excavations were conducted to more fully investigate an area where outside domestic activities were performed and where household trash was dumped. Test units were also placed in three house floors dating to the nineteenth century that had not previously been excavated.

The Nu‘alolo investigations included the analysis of previously excavated artifacts curated at Bishop Museum in Honolulu, Hawai‘i. These artifacts were collected during a research project in the 1950s and 1960s. Four house platforms dating to the nineteenth century were identified within the excavated area. The analysis completed for this dissertation focused on the assemblage of “foreign” artifacts such as glass beads, cloth fragments, and pieces of metal, ceramics, and glass. These artifacts, while previously inventoried, had not yet been subjected to detailed analysis.

This research contributes to discussions about social and cultural transformations in colonial settings by providing a compelling case study from early nineteenth-century Hawai‘i. While it has often been assumed that experiences of indigenous groups in colonial settings are homogeneous, this project emphasizes the role of local community dynamics in shaping the realities of social transformation. Although much archaeological research has been done in Hawai‘i, the overwhelming majority of this research has concerned the pre-contact period. While historical writings provide detailed accounts of Hawai‘i’s early colonial period from the perspective of elite Hawaiians and those living in urban centers, little is understood about how the happenings documented in Hawai‘i’s central regions varied from those outside the most populated areas. This project provides valuable information about the lives of Hawaiians who do not appear in historical accounts. Moreover, it helps to show that change in colonial settings was not uniform but highly variable and based largely on local circumstances.

This project has provided beneficial training opportunities for archaeology students at both the College of William & Mary and the University of Hawai‘i. Undergraduate students were taught archaeological fieldwork skills such as excavation and procedures for mapping and taking samples, as well as techniques for handling, cleaning, and sorting artifacts and archaeological specimens in a laboratory setting. As a collaborative venture between the College of William & Mary and Hawai‘i State Parks, this project has provided support for Hawai‘i State Parks’ investigations of cultural resources on public lands. Presentations at both Hawai‘i and national archaeology conferences are planned, as is a public presentation to local stakeholders on Kaua‘i Island. A preliminary report has been submitted to the State of Hawai‘i and Hawai‘i State Parks. One journal article is in progress, and two more additional publications are planned.
